titleStmt.title: Lancaster his allarums, honorable assaultes, and supprising of the block-houses and store-houses belonging to Fernand Bucke in Brasill With his braue attempt in landing in the mouth of the ordinaunce there, which were cannons culuering, cannon periall and sacres of brasse, with other sundry his most resolute and braue attempts in that country. From whence he laded of their spoyles and rich commodities he there found fifteene good ships, which was sinemon, sugar, pepper, cloues, mace, calloco-cloth and brassel-wood with other commodities. With the names of such men of worth hauing charge within this most honorable attempt lost their liues. Published for their eternall honor. by a vvelvviller.
titleStmt.author: H. R. (Henry Roberts), fl. 1585-1616.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 49 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 14 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Lancaster his allarums, honorable assaultes, and supprising of the block-houses and store-houses belonging to Fernand Bucke in Brasill With his braue attempt in landing in the mouth of the ordinaunce there, which were cannons culuering, cannon periall and sacres of brasse, with other sundry his most resolute and braue attempts in that country. From whence he laded of their spoyles and rich commodities he there found fifteene good ships, which was sinemon, sugar, pepper, cloues, mace, calloco-cloth and brassel-wood with other commodities. With the names of such men of worth hauing charge within this most honorable attempt lost their liues. Published for their eternall honor. by a vvelvviller.
titleStmt.author: H. R. (Henry Roberts), fl. 1585-1616.

publicationStmt.publisher: By A[bel] I[effes] for VV. Barley and are to be solde at his shop in Gratious-streat neer vnto Leadenhall gate,

notesStmt.note: Dedication signed: H.R., i.e. Henry Roberts.
The first leaf bears a woodcut and signature-mark "A".
Running title reads: Captaine Lancasters valiant exploytes done in Brasill.
Variant: with an added leaf after C3 with text praising Captain Randolph Cotton; text begins: But especially Captaine Randolph Cotton ..
Reproduction of a photostat of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LANCASTER his Allarums, honorable A≈ø≈øaultes, and ≈øuppri≈øing of the Block-hou≈øes and Store-hou≈øes belonging to Fernand Bucke in BRASILL.

With his braue attempt in Landing in the mouth of the Ordinaunce there, which were Cannons Culuering, Cannon periall and Sacres of bra≈ø≈øe, with other ≈øundry his mo≈øt re≈øolute and braue attempts in that COVNTRY.

From whence he laded of their ≈øpoyles and rich commodities he there found fifteene good Ships, which was Sinemon, Sugar, Pepper, Cloues, Mace, Calloco-cloth and Bra≈ø≈øel-wood with other commodities. With the names of ≈øuch men of worth hauing charge within this mo≈øt honorable attempt lo≈øt their liues. Publi≈øhed for their eternall HONOR.
by a VVelvviller.
Imprinted at London by A. I. for V V. Barley and are to be ≈øolde at his ≈øhop in Gratious-≈øtreat neer vnto Leadenhall gate.

div.head: To the mo≈øte re≈øolute and valiant minded Captaine Iames Lanca≈øter all encrea≈øe of valour with your mo≈øt worthy harts de≈øire and pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in all your Attempts.
div.p: IT hath beene [right] woorthy Captaine, their cu≈øtome in elder times among≈øt ≈øome forraine nations which held honor in regarde by all ≈øignes and ≈øhowes of toy to welcome home ≈øuch Aduenturers that for their Countreys honor and Princes benefit had any way aduentured, not only dooing them all the publicke honor they could, but inue≈øted them with titles of all honor, (≈øuch Cu≈øtomes) albeit among the vulgar ≈øorte, it be deuyed, yet doubtle≈ø≈øe tho≈øe good mindes which honor armes, and their Countrey aduentures, attribute vnto them honorable pray≈øe as they de≈øerue.

Among≈øt many other (valorious Captaine) that honor your woorthy deeds de≈øirous to regi≈øter your noble actions among≈øt the be≈øt de≈øeruing, as they woorthily merit, though my ≈ølender skill be not ≈øuch as may de≈øerue to regi≈øter ≈øo notable and woorthy exploite by you perfourmed: yet haue I boldly attempted to ≈øet downe the ≈øame, that our Countreymen ≈øpecially ≈øuch as stand vpon tearmes of being what they are not, enuying the vertues and well de≈øeruing. Aduenturer might blu≈øh to beholde what you haue perfourmed, through Gods ≈øufferance and your politik and mo≈øt valiaunt re≈øolution: whil≈øt they lye ≈øweating one their ea≈øie beddes, of which I humblye craue pardon who intends well vnto all men but e≈øpeciall bend my deuotion, vnto ≈øuch skilfull aduentures at ≈øea, for that my profe≈ø≈øion is ≈øuch, who am, and euer wilbe readie in all true zealous affection and doe you all the be≈øt ≈øeruice I can or may, when and where it ≈øhall ≈øtand with your good plea≈øure for to commaund mee.

closer.signed: Your deuoted vvellvv ‚Ä¢ iller. H. R.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.l: Nor idle toyes to meruaile at,
But woorkes of woorth mo≈øt rare & true
which to the braue≈øt mindes may be,
may know what worthy mindes they bea ‚Ä¢
May witne≈ø≈øe well vnto his fame,
Rare are his acts, peru≈øe them then,
His haughtie deeds doone to our foes,
and write but what is true:
And you that ≈øaw the welth he brought,
If London-mercha ‚Ä¢ nts dare to doe,
Then why ≈øhould not then acts be tolde,
He is the man who≈øe courage great.
He is the man that formo≈øt was,
The foeman dooth commend thy worth,
Extoll his pray≈øe which hath de≈øerude,
And gallant Brutes which yet are bound,
When time ≈øhall make you free againe,
Learne by this man of woorth to guyde,
By land or ≈øea to gaine renowne,
He is a lamp to light you one,
Learne by his woorth that valiantly‚ñ™
in place where he hath beene.
His deeds at large doe but peru≈øe,
an act of more re≈øolue hath not,

div.head: THE mo≈øt honorable Attempts and fortunate ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of our vvoorthy Citizen and braue minded Generall Iemes Lanca≈øter, and his A≈ø≈øociates,
div.p: THAT a Prophet is not e≈øt√©emed in his owne Cuntrey, it hath b√©ene often ≈øaide, and not ≈øo commonly ≈øayd, but true ≈øayd: as is mani ‚Ä¢ e≈øt in our vngratefull Cuntreymen which holde Honours Champions in account longer then the pre≈øent occa≈øion of v≈øe ≈øerueth for them.

Which maketh vs ≈øo common a by woord among≈øt other Nations for our vngratefullnes: If w√©e could a≈øwell imitate in good actions ≈øuch noble Straungers as haue liued in elder time as follow, their vanities and manners in all vicieus exerci≈øes, w√©e might well be noted for the mo≈øte only people of the whole earth: Then might that mo≈øt excellent Hi≈øtories which now declare the noble and bountifull mindes of the Romaines bee ≈øhut vp, and our Hi≈øtories fill the eares of all Nations with reportes of our now liuing and braue minded aduentures, but tho≈øe times be pa≈øt, ≈øuch men liue not to recompence their worthines nor tho≈øe of learning to giue them their due.

If Roome the abiect of earth now for her vice, hath b√©ene fur ‚Ä¢ ≈øhed with ≈øuch noble Cittizens that gained both for their valour and bountie ≈øuch eternall p ‚Ä¢ ar≈øes, not ‚Ä¢ nly for hazarding in many perrills their goods, but their owne per≈øons, arming at nothing but honor: e≈øt√©eming the goodes gotten as thinges tran≈øitorie.
Why ≈øhould not our thri ‚Ä¢ e famous Cittie of London the only wounder of the earth for beautie, gouernment and welth, holde their honor in like account?

The Romaines exalted all men of woorth for their vertues not regarding their parentage, makeing the ig-noble and ba≈øe horne tribunes Senatours and Vice-rois in their territories, h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ring them with all titles of nobilitie and honour, and after their victoryes, cau≈øed them in tryuÃÑphs, to ride throughout their Citties erecting Trophies, in memorie of their actions. Thorough which, they encouraged the noble minded, and moued the mo≈øt ba≈øe≈øt groome to aduenture.

Yf ≈øuch were the manners and conditions, of our minded cuntrymen how flori≈øhing an e≈øtate might we boa≈øt of: But we, forgetting vertue, e≈øt√©eme wealth, not vallor, (not men) before money, but money farre before men:

Yet are there ≈øome of wor≈øhippe, Patrones of this famous and mo≈øt renowned Cittie, who e≈øt√©eming their Cuntries benifit, haue by their great charge, enriched the Common-welth: And ofther carfull loue to their cuntry, enlarge ‚Ä¢ the Nauy of our Land, by their mo≈øt bountifull ex≈øpences, ≈øo that thorough a number of wor≈øhipfull Cittizens, our eneimies are weakned, our ≈øtreingth increa≈øed, our eneimies empoueri≈øhed, and our Land enriched, all for our cuntryes honor, where at they ayme as is dayly ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e by the great aduentures they make.

And I could recite, but time cau≈øeth me to admit them, and their wor≈øhipes names in this place, not doubling but in time, ≈øome of good learning for honor of our Land‚ñ™ will regi≈øter their names to eternall honor, vnto ≈øuch I commend them, to recouÃÑt vnto you, this late≈øt and mo≈øt rare exploit of a mo≈øt re≈øolute and braue Gentleman a Cittizen of this mo≈øt famous Cittie vppon our enimies the ≈øpaniards‚ñ™ wherin as he got fame by this mo≈øt re≈øolute & braue attempt, purcha≈øing ther by his cuntries honor & benifit of our commonweale, and that his vertues b√©eing a Cittizen of this famous Cittie of London though by birth of gentillity might not be ob ‚Ä¢ cured, I haue ≈øet downe his proc√©edings in this action, that our braue minded youthes in tyme to come ≈øeeing what hath hath bendone, by men of our time, may „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to the vertues & end ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oring to de≈øerue like him, honor in his ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ntry, & remaine a terror to all enymies.

In September now la≈øt pa≈øt 1594 the≈øe wor≈øhipfull, graue Cityzens, and fathers of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ London ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and mo≈øt faithfull ≈øubiectes
to our Prince, and Country, the woor≈øhipfull, Iohn Wats, Alderman, ma≈øter Paul Baning Alderman, ma≈øter Sute Salter, ma≈øter Boreman and others of woor≈øhip in this mo≈øt famous Cittie, de≈øirous for their Cuntries honor and benefit to employ their ≈øub≈øtance, victuled and equiped for all n√©edfull things is ≈øo hard and daungerous a voyage appertaining thr√©e good Ships, videl, the Con≈øent of the burthen of 240. tunnes or there about the Salomon of 170. tunnes or there about, and the Virgine 60, tunnes or there abouts, appointing for Commaunders in this voyage Iames Lanca≈øter of London Gentleman, Generall of the Fl√©ete, Mun Barker of London Viz-Admirall, and Iohn Awdley of Popler n√©er London their Reare-Admirall, hauing in their company Iohn Wats the Sonne of Alderman Wats a proper and forward Gentleman full of re≈øolution. And Symon Boreman ≈øonne of M. Boreman Owner of the Salomon, a toward and likely youth.

The≈øe forenamed ≈øhippes fully equipped and furni≈øhed with all n√©edfull proui≈øion mo≈øte royally, departed from Blackwallrood n√©er London, in October la≈øt pa≈øt, k√©eping our owne Coa≈øt clo≈øe abourd, where they met with fowle weather, ≈øuch gu≈øts and ≈øtormes that the Salomon ≈øpending her Ma≈øt not far from Darkmouth; they put into harbour and by the care and earne≈øt indu≈øtrie of the Generall and other hauing charge were ≈øhortly againe prouided, which doone, the carefull Generall loth to make longer ≈øtay then was n√©edfull hauing a plea≈øing gale for their purpo≈øe: put from Darckmouth the la≈øt of Nouember following, applying as winde ≈øerued for their de≈øired place.

But contrary to our expect, (as God by many fauours tryeth his heople) not fiftie leauges from our owne Coa≈øt w√©e lo≈øt the Salomon and the Virgine, yet being alone, in hope to m√©et them about graund Canaries or capeblanck we kept our cour≈øe for the place, and as God ≈øent vs fauorable windes plyed vntill we came to the Canaries, but could heare no tydinges of our Con≈øorts, which greatly cumbred vs: Thence went wee bearing for Timreef, where in the moruing earely w√©e had ≈øight of a ≈øayle who being becalm ‚Ä¢ d vnder the ≈øhoare, was towing with their boate a heade, hauing one other at her ≈øtearne, for this ≈øayle we mande our boate apointing our men well for fight
if neede ≈øhould ≈øerue them, but the cowardly Portugales ≈ø√©eing our boate come, entred theirs, and leauing the ≈øhip ≈øought to ≈øaue them≈øelues by flight, but our men being full of courage, hartned on with the braue imb ‚Ä¢ ld ‚Ä¢ ing ≈øpeach of our Generall, and in hope of ≈øome better good by getting the men, pur≈øued them ≈øo fa≈øt and with ≈øuch e ‚Ä¢ ar de≈øire, that they bourded them and brought them with their ≈øhippe to our Generall.
This was laden with Canarie wine, which came not vnto vs before it was well, (and better welcome.)

This ≈øhippe wee maned and kept, plying that day and the next night there abouts, the very next morning wee had ≈øight ‚Ä¢ one other, but not ≈øo much woorth as the fir≈øt was, which had eightie tunnes of wine the other but fortie.

To her in like manner wee ≈øent our Boat, but their Gunner beeing ‚Ä¢ drunken Flemming ≈øtandding on his tearmes, made a ≈øhotte at her, and ≈øhot a propper yo ‚Ä¢ ngmans arme, it wee enforced them to ≈øtrike, and to take that part their Counreymen did.

A lamentable tale it were to di≈øcouer the pittiefull lookes of the poore Portugales, who tru≈øting to our Lady ha ‚Ä¢ no hope of her ≈øonne for comfort Well, w√©eing po≈ø≈øe≈øt with this good liquor, a ≈øub≈øtance which mu≈øt vnite the life, (pray≈øed God for it) and that other good releif w√©e found among≈øt them beeing therewith well refre≈øh ‚Ä¢ d.

The Portugales h ‚Ä¢ uing their fr√©e pa≈ø≈øage, and an acquittance for deliue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of their wines‚ñ™ were all ≈øet a ≈øhoare, on Tene reefe making a quick returne o ‚Ä¢ their long voyage, who were bound for Margareta, in the Indies.

The men hauing their di≈øharge, and all thinges out that might ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ vs a ‚Ä¢ y good, we left ye place plying for Cape-blanck: but before we come thether, wee met againe with the Virgine there are Admyrall, who haling vs tolde vs for very trueth the Salomon was gonne for England, enforced ≈øo to doe by ≈øpending her m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t, which wee found contrarie, for comming to Capeblanck w√©e met the Salomon who had fi≈øhed with the Can ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ookes the be≈øt ‚Ä¢ i≈øh and other commodities h√©e found in ryfling twentie foure ≈øhippes and Caruels.

Of this good companie w√©e were all ioyfull, and had great
hope of the ble≈ø≈øing of God in performance of our intended voyage, and ≈øo after ≈øome parle and making frolick for ioy ‚Ä¢ of our m√©eting‚ñ™ one with the other pray≈øing God f ‚Ä¢ r all, wee plyed for Mayeo, where comming to ancor, our Generall and the r ‚Ä¢ ≈øt of the Cap ‚Ä¢ anes went a ≈øhoare to vein the place where we might in be≈øt ≈øafetie ≈øet our gallie together, which frame we brought from England‚ñ™ of purpo≈øe to land men in the Cuntrey.

H√©ere we di≈øcharged our great pryze of wine and ≈øet her on fire, but before our comming thether, you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand wee had ≈øight of foure ≈øayles which was Captaine Venard in his ≈øhi ‚Ä¢ pe the P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ v ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ e‚ñ™ and a proper
‚Ä¢ iskane which he tooke at Capeblanck, the Welcome of Plimmought and her Pynnes, all which ≈øtood with vs. But they ≈øeing our flagges expecting ≈øuch good fellowes as we, did beare from vs all the might, which our people tooke very vnkindely that beeing all freinds they would neither enquire, nor tell vs any newes of our freinds but without making any ≈øhow of kindnes ≈øo to depart.
From Capeblanck wee tooke likewi≈øe with vs thr√©e ≈øhippes viz. one daintie Caruell and one Canter, with one other Bark for to ≈øerue vs in the Cuntrey drawing little water for diuers purpo≈øes.

As before I haue ≈øayd, the choice b√©eing made for the place to build the Gallie, a ≈øhore it was brought, where the carpenters did their true intents, and faithfully applyed their worke‚ñ™ ≈øtill ch√©ered vnto it by the generalls good giftes be≈øtowed among≈øt them, and kind v≈øage of all the re≈øt commaunders, not with out great care of the Captaine for the ≈øaftie of them all by k√©eping good watch, yet one negligent fellow which had no knowledge of the Cuntry ≈øtraing from his companie, was by the Mooers taken, and very kindely v≈øed, and brought a gaine vnto vs, for which good, the generall rewarded them well with giftes very acceptabell‚ñ™ which they tooke as kindly.

While we were thus bu≈øily imployed about the fore≈ø ‚Ä¢ yd gallie we de≈øcry ‚Ä¢ d at ≈øea 4 ≈øayles, which we had good hope woulde haue proued Indies men or ≈øome to haue brought vs what we looked for‚ñ™ but they proued, Captaine Venard with his fleet as a fore≈øayde, who ≈øeei ‚Ä¢ g vs at ancor came in vnto vs, a ‚Ä¢ cored al≈øo, where ≈øpending ≈øome time, and beeing acquainted with
‚Ä¢ ur Generalls determination, for laÃÑding con≈øorted with vs, and their b ‚Ä¢ lis according, to the manner of the ≈øea were made, and ≈øigned, of other parte, whereby our ≈øtrength was encrea≈øed to all our comforts, thr√©e w√©ekes or there abouts we ≈øtayed in this place, before the Gally was fini≈øhed which done putting men into her, and fitting her with ores, hauing 14 bankes on a ≈øide, a ma≈øte and ≈øayle, the commaundment of her was committed vnto ma≈øter Wats an hone≈øt ≈økilfull maryner.

From thence we put againe to ≈øea and hope of like ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and went for the Ile Dett Brauo where we watered, which done we made no long ≈øtay after, but bent our cour≈øe as derectly as we could for the place, but before we came thither we lo≈øt our Caruell and one of the other pry≈øes, our owne ≈øhipps beeing all well and in good ≈øaftie, which thankes to god, the comforte of all that builde faythfully vpon him, by who≈øe ≈øufferance we recouered the place, making our fir≈øt fall with the land to the ≈øouthward of Cape Augu≈øtine from whence we applyed ≈øtill to our de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ red Port of Farnand Bucke, and did ≈øo much, that about midnight, we came before the harbor where ≈øome plyed vp & downe, holding that the be≈øt pollicy, to forbear the entring till day might giue them light, the harbought being hard and therfore the more perillous.

Our Shippes being in ≈øaftie well ariued, God was pray≈øed, and the Generall in his boat went from ≈øhippe to ≈øhip, willing them to make ready ≈øuch men as they could ≈øpare, with mu≈økets, pykes bylles, bowes, arrowes and what weapons they had to follow him: Him ≈øelf, with foure≈øcore men from his owne ≈øhippe, embarqued him ≈øelfe in the Gallie which carryed in her prowe a good Sacare.

The Inhabitaunts which ≈øaw ≈øo much ≈øhipping, dreading what did follow, were gathered togither by e≈øtimatien to the number of 1000 men and from their platforme beeing oppi≈øite with the harboughts mouth well planted with Cannon periall and Sacars of bra≈ø≈øe plyed vpon vs with them, our ≈øhippes ryding within Sacar-≈øhot in the very face of them, yet did they not hurt any ≈øhippe but our Gunners borrowed little of them, but payd them well what≈øoeuer they ≈øent among≈øt vs‚ñ™ and with ≈øuch ≈øound payment, that two ≈øhot from the Admyrall by Gods
help and the Gunners good indu≈øtrie, beat their wateh-hou≈øe about their ‚Ä¢ ares.

This beginning made the faint harted ≈øwades to quaile that their harts were in coun≈øayle with ther h√©eles, which ≈øhould be t ‚Ä¢ e be≈øt member, in the end by generall con≈øent, they agr√©ed‚ñ™ to ≈ø√©e a littell more, intreating their h√©eles to be redy to make ≈øhifte for them.

But our Generall otherwi≈øe imployed his men b√©eing ≈øhipped rowed to the ≈øhore, all the nyght appoynted with his companies, and encouraging his m ‚Ä¢ n in the very face of the Platforme and mouth of their Ordinaunce landed, leaping to the wa≈øte in water, in the breach of the ≈øhoare, his men following him leauing their Gallye which beate ≈øo on the ≈øhoare as ≈øhee did little other ≈øeruice, a notable pollicie of the Generall, if h√©e had b√©ene matcht with cowards‚ñ™, which the Generall little regarded making that a tryall, and encouraging his men, cryed ≈øtil Saint George braue gallants this is our owne.

The white liuored Crauius as they be proude cowardes not re≈øpecting the aduantage they had of our people b√©eing ≈øo wette, which ‚Ä¢ a≈øely they might haue foyled, like harmele≈ø≈øe hone≈øtmeÃÑ tru≈øting to their olde freindly heeles their cheife≈øt comfort, leauing the Generall in po≈ø≈øe≈øion of all, ≈øaued them≈øelues ≈øome in boates, which lay ready at the back ≈øide the hou≈øe, others for the be≈øt prize, made our men Iudges who was the be≈øt footemen, flying ≈øo fa≈øt as a hare from the egar greygound hauing not ≈øo much kindenes to bid them welcome, nor hone≈øtie to bid them farwell, the day of our arriuall was their Good-Fryday, when by cu≈øtome they v≈øuall whippe them ≈øelues, but God ≈øent vs now for a generall ≈øcourge for them all, wherby that labour among≈øt them might be well ≈øpared, for ≈ømall lea≈øure they had to doe that ‚Ä¢ opperie.

The Generall waued the ≈øhippes willing them to waye and to come in, which they did with all ≈øpeed, him≈øelf taking order with his A≈ø≈øociates of what they had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and turning the Ordinance bent them that way they expected any anoyance from the towneward, made choyce of a place conuenient for to builde a baracad ‚Ä¢ , which ≈øtrongly they fortified, brought the Ordinance from the Fort and placed them in theirs, what they
could be≈øt v≈øe, the re≈øt they ≈øent a bourd, their ≈øhippes k√©eping good and carefull watch: Now it is to be remembred, that in this „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ they ‚Ä¢ ound three great Hulcks which came thether ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in Syaine to being tho≈øe goodes home which was there left, now two reares ≈øince, by a Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ck which was ca≈øt away.

Our Generall hauing in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Towne with all the goodes in the Storehou≈øes, ≈øent for the Flemings and demaunded what they did there: they an≈øwered for the≈øe goods they came ≈øent from Spaine by the honors for them, & ≈øo after ≈øome wordes betweene them agr√©ed for their fraught home to England vnto which they y√©elded.

When the≈øe thinges were thus to our comfort accompli≈øht, the Generall thought it ≈ømall pollicie to make longer ≈øtay, then was n√©edfull, and therfore tooke order from euerie ≈øhippe one to woork, ye other to watch for their ≈øecuritie. The fir≈øt ≈øeruice was done, we vnladed our wine prize giuing to euery ≈øhip equall portions, then making ready euery ≈øhippes holde, they brake the prize making it to ≈øerue for a Lighter to lade and with her the Welcomes Pynnace for the more expedition in their lading, ≈øo earne≈øtly applying them ≈øelues as no oportuniti was lo≈øt in porfourmance thereof, our wlling mindes holding it no trouble: watching by night, nor hard labour by day: but ≈øo vigilaunt they were in all there actions as was requi≈øite they ≈øhould in ≈øo perillous a place, otherwi≈øe, they had enioyed their good fortunes but a ≈ømall time, ≈øuch was the pollicie of tho≈øe ba≈øe roges, who in ye night at one time fyred i ‚Ä¢ . Caruills apollic ‚Ä¢ e to their co≈øt learned in England, but perfourmed like them ≈øelues, for the Caruills with the fire taking like harmele≈ø≈øe boates a quite contrary way ran a ≈øhore con≈øuming them ≈øelues without any anioyance to our ≈øhips as they intended they ≈øhould haue done.

This deuice ≈øorting to no better effect, they made rafts with olde ma≈øts and grapling them together and planting them full of light wood heath and ≈øuch, fired them and ≈øent them among≈øt our ≈øhippes, for this deui≈øe our Generall ordained from euerie ≈øhippe two boates to be ready a head each ≈øhippe hauing in each one of them a graplet to throw on the rafts which ≈øunck them all and neuer had an a ‚Ä¢ uantage to doe vs harme, the≈øe deui≈øes qualing by ≈øea, euery night they gaue vs bra ‚Ä¢ ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , one the
≈øhore bringing ≈øome few naked men with vowes and arrowes before our ≈øcence, which ≈øhot often without dooing ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, all which was to draw vs within compa≈ø≈øe of their ambu≈øhment, which they had laid in hope we ≈øhould haue pur≈øued them flying but our Generalls and Captaines had more fore≈øight then to venture them ≈øelues and vs again≈øt naked wretches

When they law that all their deui≈øe was by pollicie fru≈øtrate thinking w√©e would be carele≈ø≈øe of their dooing they began in the night to builde a new Forte in ≈øuch a place as would have greatly annoyed vs if they had gone forward with it: But our Generall hauing intelligence of the ≈øame by ≈øome of the cuntry people, would not ≈ø√©eme vnto them any way di≈øcontent but ≈øecretly in the euening quietly gathering his companies i≈ø≈øued vpon them, put them from their woorke, tooke foure p√©eces of bra≈ø≈øe Ordinaunce and ≈ø ‚Ä¢ aying thr√©e≈øcore of their men put the the re≈øt vnto flight and retourned with lo≈ø≈øe of one man, bringing with him to our forte their Ordinaunce which they intended ≈øhould haue doone vs the mi≈øcheif, this their deui≈øes ≈øorting to ≈øuch ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, euer pretending, but neuer accompli≈øhing any thing that euer did hurt vs, our men with ≈øuch care imployed them ≈øelues as was ioyfull to ≈øee them.

In this painfull trauell of fours we had ≈øight o ‚Ä¢ a ≈ømall man of warre of Deep in Fraunce who had pl ‚Ä¢ ed vp and downe two monethes yet dur≈øt not put in vntill they had ≈øight of Saint George which continually we bare in our toppes, this little Frenchman comming in ≈øaluted our Admyrall as he could after the ≈øea manner, and hoy≈øing his boat came abourd to our Generall acquainting him with his extremitie wanting victualls, who like him ≈øelf, py ‚Ä¢ tying his di≈øtre≈ø≈øe and waying the want him ≈øelf had indured in his la≈øt long voyage, with that noble Gentleman Captaine Raymond gaue him wine, bread, pea≈øe and ≈øuch victualls as he had to their great rel√©ef.

This Frenchman reported that he not long before met with Captaine Abraham Cock who beeing di≈øtre≈ø≈øed for water hee re ‚Ä¢ eiued with one hog≈øhed hauing but two in all, and brought him to a p ‚Ä¢ ace where they both watered. Not long after his arryuall, w√©e had ≈øight of thr√©e ≈øayles more which we hoped had beene India men, but prooued Frenchmen. The Generell of this
Fl√©et was that ≈øame which brought our‚ñ™ Generall from Mona, after the lo≈ø≈øe of his ≈øhippe, to our Generall was hartily welcome as was mo≈øte manife≈øt by the entertainment he gaue both him and his whole complanie wherein ≈øhowing him ≈øelf a mo≈øt braue and gratefull Gentleman farre vnlike ≈øuch ≈øhauing people which neuer think of freind≈øhip longer then they reape commoditie, catch by all meanes they can, from ≈øuch as carry gentle and willing mindes to de≈øerue well to doe good vnto them that ≈ø√©eke their fauour. Such vnt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kfull wretches I haue oftentimes ≈ø√©ene to begge for releif w ‚Ä¢ ere their piteous moanes haue b√©ene ≈øcorned.

But to out matter the Generall in this time being po≈ø≈øe≈øt wt ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ch welthie commodities ‚Ä¢ s he could not tell where to be≈øtowe after he had fraughted his owne thr√©e men of war, thr√©e flemi≈øh hulcks of great burthen, thr√©e we≈øtern ≈øhips viz. the Perygrine the Welcome and their prize with two ≈øpanyards which hee found in the roade gaue franckly vnto his good freind the Captaine what he would take of all ≈øuch commodities as they had, which was clones, mace‚ñ™ pepper, Sinemon and Calocowcloth Sugar and braffellwood wherof they had ≈øuch ≈øtore that euerie night during the k√©eping their forte a ≈øhoare they burnt by e≈øtimation aboue two tunnes. With the≈øe commodities the french man lading his thr√©e ≈øhippes and the Deep man one, and yet the Generall to ≈øhowe his further thankfulnes vnto him, gaue him fr√©ely one other ≈øhippe which came into the harbought full laden with Negers and other c ‚Ä¢ mmodities, of which he tooke his plea≈øure, this fauour the frenchman tooke in very thankfull manner, and wtih diligence had purueyed to be gone with the Fl√©et, who being near ready to leane the harbought, intelligeÃÑce was giuen them by ≈øome of the cuntrey people that ye Gouernor had prouided for making a new ≈øorte, oppo≈øit of the mouth of the harbourt, where perrilles were mo≈øt incident, and where men ≈øhould he mo≈øt bu≈øied in dooing their labour to k√©epe them from the danger of the bar, which tydings nothing ple≈øed him nor any of his companie, wherfore ≈øommoning the cheif of each ≈øhippe, vppon conference had of the daungers ≈øo bad a gue≈øt might there br√©ed being there planted it was concluded to make ≈øuch power as they could & to driue them from their labour, ≈øo to raze their
fortification, this being with adui≈øe platted and a generall likeing of the deui≈øe, care was likewi≈øe taken for perfourming the ≈øame, and euerie thing for the purpo≈øe accordingly fitt ‚Ä¢ ed: which done, the Generall that had b√©ene often by flags of truce ≈øommoned to parle with their Gouernour, which continually he refu≈øed, ≈øcorning to haue familiaritie with any his Princes enemies, a≈øwell to auoyde ≈øu≈øpect of euill tounges as for his owne reputation, was for this cau≈øe enuyed of the Generall the more, which doubtle≈ø≈øe would gladly haue beene better acquainted wt him if po≈ø≈øibly he might, and for the better bringing his deuili≈øh practi≈øes to effect, he fir≈øt began this new fortification, which he imagined our Generall would not indure, nor ≈øuffer him to perfourme, but woorking by pollicie, he ambu≈øht his people ≈ø√©eking therby his ouerthrow, whome God defended in di≈øpight of what he could or might doe, as the ≈øequell ≈øhall manife≈øt, for h√©e who≈øe hope was neither in pope, ≈øaint or help of men, determining as you haue heard to effect this new re≈øolued woorke, ranged his companies and in mo≈øt warlick and braue manner like a conqueror marched on to their forte, where with ≈øuch courage he a≈ø≈øayled the defendants as made them bel√©eue there ≈øhoulde few e≈øcape, which made them play their olde parts, and tru≈øting to their be≈øt freinds, their nymble h√©eles tournned their backes and departed: Who≈øe da≈øtardly minds our men di≈ødaining with eger pur≈øute followed ≈øpoyling many, but they that thought on no manhood but pollicie, con ‚Ä¢ aide them ≈øelues into a wood, clo≈øly followed of our people, into which, they were no ≈øooner entered, but in fight of our people was placed xvij. En≈øignes that made on towards them, and looking behinde them they were backed with ≈øo many be≈øides tho≈øe runawaies in the wood. This ≈øight cau≈øed our people to ≈øtand and better to con≈øider for their ≈øafties what to doe, who knowing that delay bread daungers de≈øirous to ≈øhow their re≈øolution in maintaining that honor which mo≈øt valiaÃÑtly they had alreadie obtained, rather were de≈øirous to aduenture their good fortunes with the ≈øwoorde, then to loo≈øe what they had ≈øo honorably gained: ≈øubiecting them ≈øelues vnto ≈øo mercele≈ø≈øe enemies.

And h√©eron re≈øoluing like Engli≈øhmen, who was as yet neuer knowen to for≈øake the ≈øeildes where tenne hath beene to one
the enimie approching one both ≈øides, there was no remedie but to looke to them ≈øelues: which our Generall and his valiant a≈ø≈øociates ≈øeeing, placing their companies as they could be≈øt one ≈øuch a ≈øuddaine, both for defending them ≈øelues and annoying the enemie like men no whit di≈øcomforted, beholding their huge numbers which were of hor≈ø≈øe and foote, ≈øpaniardes and the Cuntrey people 5000 brauely and with great courage began the a≈ø≈øault applying their ≈ømall ≈øhot ≈øo long as their poulder la≈øted, which fiin≈øhed throwing from them their ≈øhot betooke him to their haÃÑd weapons with which they did ≈øuch wundrous ≈øpoyle as the ≈øpaniards per≈øwaded them that they fought not again≈øt men, but ≈øome of a more hori≈øh condicion.

A ≈øore and cruell battell was there beer begonne, and continued with ≈øo few to ≈øuch a multitude as ≈øeldome hath b√©ene ≈ø√©ene in the enemies cuntrey, who≈øe valiant harts were neuer dared, nor for no extremitie, although thorow their hot and earne≈øt labor in ≈øuch a broyle and in a cuntrey ≈øo contagious, many were di≈øtre≈øt for want of drink, yet minded they what they had in haÃÑd more then their bellies, playing the partes of men, and braue Engli≈øhmen defending and annoying the enemie with ≈øuch corage that the enemies wundred therat, euermore ch√©ering them ≈øelues, and the Generall chearing all, crying out to the terreur of the enemie Saint George, God for S. George Englands defence.

But in this glorie when their hopes were ≈øuch to e≈øcape all daungers, thorough the mightie hand of our God which cau≈øed ≈øo many to fall before Samp≈øon with the iaw bone: beholde a meruelous terrour vnto our men. The French Captain our Generalls great‚ñ™ Amico, leading thr√©e≈øcore of his Cuntreymen was ≈øtaine, at who≈øe fall his ‚Ä¢ ollowers being di≈øcomforted beganne to flye, ≈øhewing theirin right partes of them ≈øelues: which our men perceiuing, and knowing no cau≈øe, made ≈øhift for them ≈øelues, as the≈øe cowards did, and recouered their botes and their ≈øhippes in good ≈øafetie, backed from the raging pur≈øute of the enemie by our ≈øhippes.

In this conflict al ‚Ä¢ o was ≈ølaine Captaine Barker, Captaine Cotton two mo≈øte braue and re≈øo ‚Ä¢ ute Gentlemen and much lamented. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ fini≈øhed, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
that could „Äà‚óä„Äâ , our Generall thought that he had done mo≈øte honorably, and generally the whole companye, bewayling the lo≈ø≈øe of his good freind the french gentleman ≈ølaine, cryed out of cowardice of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe ba≈øer groomes his followers, per≈øwading him ≈øelf that if they had ≈øtood with them the honor of this comrie had beene theirs, ≈øo great was all their hopes in his mercie, that in ≈øo many perrils ≈øince they came from their owne cuntry had ≈øo mightily pre≈øerued them. Then laboured our men to cloy that Ordinaunce we left in our Forte, which we cam ‚Ä¢ full of ≈øpykes, ≈øtones & other trumperle making them vn≈øerui≈øable.

The Generall ≈øeeing what was done, and that there was no meanes to with≈øtand ≈øo great a multitude lea≈øt armed with fooli≈øh hardines he ≈øhould end ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ger the honor h√©e had gained, (then which) hee rather would choo≈øe to dye, ≈øeeing it would bee hot abyding there, the enemie planting ≈øo n√©ere him commaunded the whole Fl√©et to make ready, bring their ancours abourd and vpon the fir≈øt of the ebbe to goe out, which with ≈øuch expedition was done, that their was no ≈øhow of any idle hands.

At this pu≈øh, beholde one other mo≈øt meruelous fauour of God toward vs, the windes which long before blew great & vehemently into the harbought mouth, had altered her place and fitted our turnes ≈øo that being ready to ≈øet ≈øayle we had a fayre top ≈øale gale which caryed vs cleare off the harbought and the barre, without receiuing any domage from the enemie, which ≈øhot franckly at vs a long time neuer hitting any one hull, but one, of our Flemings a great hulck which was as fair a marck as a Church which winde la≈øted not long, nor found wee the like, in ≈øeuen w√©ekes after: thus being deliuered from the hands of our enemies hauing in our companies of engli≈øh, french and dutch the number of fift√©ene ≈øayles laden all deep with their commodities: The Generall commaunded the whole Fl√©et to beat for Peren-Iew where hee determined to water and to take ≈øuch other proui≈øion as we could there gette, ≈øending the little Frenchman of Deepe which ≈øayled well to purcha≈øe what hee could for vs, with this place we fel about the mid≈øt of night, our Generall comming to ancour in the offine, put out his lightes that they might be therby aduerti≈øed what to doe not notwith≈øtanding ≈øome put into ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ha ‚Ä¢ bought others ouer≈øhotte it, and
w√©e in the Admyrall ryding a ≈øoute and mo≈øt better rough, were faine to ≈øhift for our ≈øelues, and put into the ≈øea, where wee lo≈øt our Fl√©et & neuer met them after until our aryu ‚Ä¢ ll in ye downes, where it was ≈øayde vnto one Generall, to his and all our comforts, that the Salomon with one ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øh hulck was come vnto London, The Peryg ‚Ä¢ ine the Welcome with their pynace and one other hulck laden were at Plimmouth, and one of the ≈øpani≈øh ≈øhippes which we laded for our owne v≈øe arriued at Brea≈øt in Brittaine, the other by mi≈øchance comming foule of another ≈øhippe was broken down to the water which our men left in the ≈øea, the frenchmen with th ‚Ä¢ u fiue ≈øhippes are as wee heare all arryued in ≈øafetie‚ñ™ our ≈øhippe with the Virgine and one other hulck being the la≈øt that came home, who≈øe long ≈øtay made our freindes greatly to doubt of our well dooings. But pray≈øe to his ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e name that bath ≈øo pre≈øerued vs all, and ≈øent vs with ≈øuch happie fortune among≈øt our friends with no great lo≈ø≈øe, though ≈øome we had, among≈øt which, that o≈øt their liues and mo≈øt lamented was Captaine Venard whome we buryed royally in the cuntry, the other our Ma≈øter Chiurgion Randall Starkey a man of ≈øingul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll and as good gouernment as may be required, who of the di≈øea≈øe called the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ dyed & was there buryed, and almo≈øt all our Chiurgions‚ñ™ one only excepted, of wh ‚Ä¢ ≈øe help God be glorified, we had little noode, vntill our arriuall in the downes, where a mo≈øt ≈øore and gr√©enous mi≈øc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nce befell vs, thorow the ne ‚Ä¢ ligence of our ma≈øter Gunner, who≈øe carele≈ø≈øe dooings made vs all full hea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, a ‚Ä¢ ter a mo≈øt trouble
‚Ä¢ ome and hard aduentures to be at our owne doores when euery man made ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ co ‚Ä¢ ing to ≈øollace him with his freindes, then by ≈øuch a ca≈øuall hap to be ≈øpoyled as we were, for the Gunnor him ≈øelf was ≈ølaine with two others, and twentie others gre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t.

A woorthy ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rour for all men of gouernment taking charge, how ≈øo carele≈ø≈øely they demaine them ≈øelues, looking with more care vnto the charge vnto them committed, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as haue the commaund of poulder and ≈øuch like ≈øub≈øtance which is not to be ‚Ä¢ e≈øted withall, the proofe thereof hath beene to often ≈øoone, to the great damage of the woor≈øhipfull Owners. But e≈øpecially Captaine Randolph Cotton who≈øe courage in mid≈øt of all broyles neuer quailed: this braue and worthy minded Gentleman albeit he had end ‚Ä¢ rde mo≈øt hard and ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l cro≈ø≈øes in his la≈øt aduenture to the ≈øea, accompaning that mo≈øte renew
‚Ä¢ ed and forward Gentleman Thomas Candi≈øh E≈øquire, who held him for his vertues in great account: The remembrance of who≈øe death; with gr√©e ‚Ä¢ he often times bewayled, and the many cares and troubles of that mo≈øt vnfortunate voyage not yet exiled out of his minde, deffrous to make once againe tryall of his fortunes: arming his neuer conquered minde for the ≈øame, re≈øeluing ‚Ä¢ ther to gaine fame which before welth he pryzed, not like tho≈øe peny fathers which care not who loo≈øe ≈øo they gaine, expecting but opportunitie and ≈øuch companie, as he wi≈øhed, re≈øted ≈øo, vntill our Generalls arriuall at Darckmouth where hee made his abode, with whome hauing conference, and knowing his pretended voyage was for the≈øe confines of Fernand Bucke, & that his determination was to land, thought this a time fitting his minde, wherfore without any de≈øire to ≈øee his be≈øt freinds, kynne or allyes, which commonly draw men from many attemptes, h√©e not only aduentured his mony in the action but his bodye, with who≈øe good companie the Generall was well plea≈øed, and all the re≈øt of his comp√©eres, hauing great hope of his valor‚ñ™ which not only ≈øhowed in his manly countenance, but ≈øpecially induced ther vnto by the rare reportes of his forward attempts in many other actions where h√©e had charge a≈øwell by ≈øea as by land.

An in≈øtance of which was manife≈øted by tho≈øe that acccompaned that mo≈øt rare and famous Captaine and Nauigator Iohn Va ‚Ä¢ es, whereby his good coun≈øaile in times of extremities, and valiant corage in all times of ≈øeruice, hee gayned by curte≈øie the ≈øole loue and generall likeing of all the companie.

All which good partes conioyning in this woorth Gentleman, mooued the Generall with con≈øent of his freinds & compheres, to elect him for their principall leader for their land ≈øeruice as one who≈øe ≈økil ‚Ä¢ and mo≈øte woorthy re≈øolution they wholely vnder God re ‚Ä¢ yed vppon‚ñ™ which was euery way an≈øwerable to what they expected, ≈øo that therein they were not deceiued at all, as his ge ‚Ä¢ at care in perfourming that charge was vnto him committed did manife≈øt,

For what many men accounted great paine and mo≈øte trouble≈øome labour h√©e held and e≈øt√©emed as m√©ere plea≈øure, ≈øuch diligent care he had in k√©eping on ≈øhore, ≈øuch vigilaunt watch and warde bothe for his companies ≈øecurite as his owne, as was nece≈ø≈øary and mo≈øt conuenient to be v≈øed in a place of ≈øuch daunger.

Be≈øides his hard labour in buylding thr√©e Baracadoes where he framed his hands which in ≈øuch labours had b√©ene v≈øually accou≈øtomed to toyle and take paine, whereby he might drawe on others and the better to encorage them to their bu≈øines and careful indu≈øtrie,

Euer, and in euerie attemt ≈øhowing both val ‚Ä¢ our and re≈øolution in his actions as≈øwell ≈øeene at the ≈øupprizing of their enemies fir≈øt begunne forte, where giuing a mo≈øt couragious on≈øet, put them from their woorke and ≈øupprizing their Ordinaunce, and with no ≈ømall honor mo≈øt valiantly brought it vnto to their Forte.

This woorthy and mo≈øt valiant Gentleman as hee was forward to accompli≈øh tho≈øe actions which to ≈øuch valiant and re≈øolute exploites belonged, ≈øo was he a vnto his followers a≈ø well of re≈øolute a≈ø≈øaults as of carefull indu≈øtrie a ≈øpectacle in his enterpri≈øes, neuer damited or receceiuing foyle vntill the fatall time of his death, which hononorably he receiued.

Thus ≈øhowing him ≈øelf a mo≈øt woothy leader and faithfull ≈øubiect to his Prince and Cimtrey, leading his companies to this venterous and rare exploite, inuironed with the extremitie of tho≈øe ba≈øe and cowardly pea≈øants, who takeing him at a vantage was mo≈øt butcherly murthered without regarde either of his vertues or valour.

But the cruell tyranny of tho≈øe dete≈øtable wretches ≈øhall nor can blemi≈øh his de≈øerued fame nor obliuion extingui≈øh his re≈øolute actions, wherby he woorhyly de≈øerued ≈øuch memorie as tung or pen can or may render for requitall a≈øwell of his vertuous behauiour, carefull indu≈øtry and re≈øolution in all his actions,

With whome there dyed that valiant Captaine Mun Barker, bothe which as long as they liued ≈øo encouraged our people, that there was no feare among≈øt them, but euerie one re≈øolued to fight it out who≈øe death was greatly lamented among≈øt vs all,
This Battle fini≈øhed, and all men come abourde the ≈øhippes that

Thus good Reader I haue truly di≈øcour≈øed vnto you the troubles of this our voyage which to the glorie of God and our Cuntries woorthy de≈øerued commendations I haue h√©ere explayned, that you which beholde the wunders God hath done for vs and our Cuntrey may with vs and w√©e with you pray≈øe him, and hartely de≈øire that neuer woor≈ø≈øe ≈øucces befall any of our nation‚ñ™ that as w√©e haue done fight and aduenture in ≈øuch ha≈ø≈øard for our Prince and Cuntrey who≈øe life and honor God euer maintaine to the terrour of all dome≈øticall enemies, & the ouerthrowe of all tho≈øe that wi≈øh her or vs ill.

div.head: A Commemoration of tho≈øe vvoorthy and valiant Gentlemen Captaine Barker and his freind Captaine Cotton who in this mo≈øte honorable Attempt lo≈øt their liues.

lg.l: GAallants of England Mar≈øes cho≈øen pheres,
Braue men of worth Chau ‚Ä¢ leres of Fame:
Lay armes a≈øide, and poure forth brini≈øh teares,
VVayling their lo≈ø≈øe whom cowarde foes hath ≈ølaine.
Barker braue man, the honor of thy name,
Who≈øe hautye deedes, yet ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in warre:
In cheife≈øt mirth doth cau≈øe our tunes to iarre.
And courtious Cottonne for his braue attempt,
Did≈øt well de≈øerue a worthy Captaines place
Their valiant force the≈øe ≈øpaniards proud haue felt,
Which purcha≈øe fame vnto thier great di≈øgrace
Pur≈øuing foes like lions in their cha≈øe,
Fighting in right of cuntry and our Queene
Like men of worth, mo≈øt re≈øolute and ≈øterne.
In mid≈øt of broyles where foes were ten to one,
Thier ≈øhot beeing ≈øpent, a wunder twas to ≈øee:
How many ≈øpaniards, by them to death were brought,
Crying S. George, ≈øweete England now for thee:
The warcke of ≈øpaine, we haue good hope to ≈øee.
This ≈øayd tho≈øe gallants, and euen therewithall,
A luckele≈ø≈øe ≈øtrook cau≈øde Barker dead to fall.
Who≈øe death fearce Cottonne required ≈øo‚ñ™
That many a foe, by him to hell was ≈øent:
So ≈øhewed this man of worth his force gain≈øt foe,
Who≈øe hart with rigor to reuenge was bent.
But chance of warre, hath often wrong euent,
In cheife≈øt hope, to haue a ioyfull day:
A cur≈øed ≈øhot, his life hath tane away.
Thus fought tho≈øe men like champions of our Queene,
Hauing at mo≈øt in all three hundred men:
Again≈øt fiue thou≈øand which armd in feilde was ≈øeene,
Ranged to fight ≈øuch cowardes ≈øtill they benne.
Yet all their force they wayed notapyn.
But brauely then the on≈øet on them gaue,
And by their valour from their Fort them draue.
But dead they be, yea dead are both our freinds,
VVho≈øe fames ≈øhall liue eternized for ay:
That all may know how braue they made their endes.
Which whil≈øt they liude in this mo≈øt hardy fray,
Did ≈øcourge the≈øe curres and held them at a bay.
Who≈øe ≈øenceles truncks though loe enterd they lye‚ñ™
Their glorious ≈øoules both re≈øt aboue the ≈økye.
